description: From Middle English tenoun, tenown, tenon, from Anglo-Norman tenoun, from Old French tenon.

entries.meaning: A projecting member left by cutting away the wood around it, and made to insert into a mortise, and in this way secure together the parts of a frame.

verbs.description: tenon (third-person singular simple present tenons, present participle tenoning, simple past and past participle tenoned)

examples: First we'll tenon this part, then we'll make a mortise that will fit it on that part.
